channel.title: Environmental & Climate News | Reuters
channel.description: Find latest environment news from every corner of the globe at Reuters.com, your online source for breaking international news coverage.

item.title: At least 8 killed, scores injured in Algerian forest fires -state radio
item.description: At least eight people were killed and scores injured on Wednesday in wildfires in mountainous areas east of Algeria, according to state radio.
item.dc:creator: Reuters

item.title: Hungarians renew protest at 'forest destruction' as government rolls back some changes
item.description: Around a thousand Hungarians protested for the second time in less than a week against a loosening of logging regulations by Prime Minister Viktor Orban's government amid increased demand for firewood due to surging gas and electricity prices.
item.dc:creator: Reuters

item.title: Californians asked to cut power use as extreme heat approaches
item.description: Californians were urged to ratchet down the use of electricity in their homes and businesses on Wednesday as a wave of extreme heat settles over much of the state, stretching tight power supplies to their breaking point.
item.dc:creator: Reuters

item.title: France's river Loire sets new lows as drought dries up its tributaries
item.description: France's river Loire, famous for the hundreds of castles gracing its shores, is a shallow river at the best of times, but this year even its flat-bottom tourist barges can barely navigate waters greatly reduced by a record drought.
item.dc:creator: Reuters

item.title: Spanish fire crew's brush with death as Valencia wildfire rages
item.description: A cry of "run, run, run, run" rang out across the hillside as a wall of flame fed by high winds swept down towards four Spanish firefighters, engulfing tinder-dry bracken seconds after they fled for their lives.
item.dc:creator: Reuters

item.title: As southern France battles drought, water comes by truck to some villages
item.description: In Seillans, southern France, age-old stone fountains are empty, and taps in homes are only kept running - up to a strict daily limit - thanks to water trucks, because its natural springs are dry.
item.dc:creator: Reuters

item.title: Thai court throws out decade-long legal fight over Laos dam
item.description: A top Thai court on Wednesday dismissed a lawsuit seeking to halt purchases of electricity by the country from a hydropower dam in neighbouring Laos over environmental concerns, bringing an end to a decade-long legal battle.
item.dc:creator: Reuters

item.title: Serbs wade in shrinking Danube as dredgers work flat-out
item.description: Serbian sunseekers flocking to the riverside beaches of Novi Sad have adopted new pastime this summer - wading across a vast stretch of the Danube usually reserved for cargo barges and cruise ships.
item.dc:creator: Reuters

item.title: U.S. spares Western states from Colorado River water cuts
item.description: The U.S. government spared seven Western states from mandatory Colorado River water cutbacks for now but warned on Tuesday that drastic conservation was needed to protect dwindling reservoirs from overuse and severe drought exacerbated by climate change.
item.dc:creator: Reuters

item.title: London set for hosepipe ban from Aug. 24
item.description: Thames Water, which serves customers in and around the British capital London, said on Wednesday it was banning customers from using a hosepipe from Aug. 24, citing prolonged dry weather.
item.dc:creator: Reuters

item.title: China takes action to alleviate drought as record heatwave continues
item.description: China is taking emergency action to bring more water to the drought-hit basin of the Yangtze river, deploying relief funds, seeding clouds and developing new supply sources as a record-breaking heatwave damages crops and livestock.
item.dc:creator: Reuters

item.title: Torrential New Zealand rains, floods force evacuation of 200 homes-media
item.description: Torrential rains hit New Zealand's South Island on Wednesday, flooding rivers, houses and roads and forcing roughly 200 households to evacuate, media reported.
item.dc:creator: Reuters

item.title: China's Sichuan limits power to homes, offices amid extreme heat
item.description: China's southwestern province Sichuan began limiting electricity supply to homes, offices and malls on Wednesday, due to a severe power crunch driven by extreme heat waves and drought, according to state media and one power company.
item.dc:creator: Reuters

item.title: Portuguese wildfire envelops Madrid skyscrapers in smoke 400 km away
item.description: Smoke from a huge wildfire in central Portugal enveloped skyscrapers known as the "Four Towers" in Madrid 400 km (250 miles) away on Tuesday, and residents of the Spanish capital complained of a strong burning smell.
item.dc:creator: Reuters

item.title: U.S. grant of $1.66 billion for new buses aims to curb emissions
item.description: The U.S. Transportation Department said on Tuesday it is awarding $1.66 billion in grants to cities and states to buy 1,800 buses in a shift to cleaner, lower-emission travel.
item.dc:creator: Reuters

item.title: Biden signs $430 billion climate, healthcare and tax bill
item.description: President Joe Biden on Tuesday signed into law a $430 billion bill that is seen as the biggest climate package in U.S. history, designed to cut domestic greenhouse gas emissions as well as lower prescription drug prices.
item.dc:creator: Reuters

item.title: Heavy rainfall hits Paris after recent heatwave
item.description: Heavy rainfall hit Paris on Tuesday evening after a recent heatwave across France, affecting metro stations in the French capital.
item.dc:creator: Reuters

item.title: After U.S. climate bill win, environmental groups turn to permit reform
item.description: With President Joe Biden expected to sign a long-negotiated climate spending bill later on Tuesday, environmental groups are turning their focus to their next fight - halting efforts to fast-track permitting for major infrastructure projects like pipelines and highways.
item.dc:creator: Reuters

item.title: Caribbean nations should push for climate finance at COP27, Bahamas PM says
item.description: Caribbean countries should pressure developed nations to provide more financing to mitigate the effects of climate change at the upcoming COP27 climate talks, the prime minister of The Bahamas said at a summit of regional officials on Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: Reuters

item.title: EU greenhouse gas emissions on the rise, but still below pre-pandemic level
item.description: Greenhouse gas emissions across the European Union rose in the first quarter from a year earlier, but remained just below pre-pandemic levels, the bloc's statistics office said on Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: Reuters

item.title: African penguins endangered by shipping noise in Algoa Bay
item.description: The already endangered African penguin is being driven away from its natural habitat off the east coast of South Africa due to noise from ship refuelling, a scientific study has found.
item.dc:creator: Reuters

item.title: Ivory Coast rains raise farmers' hopes for cocoa crop
item.description: Above-average rains last week in most of Ivory Coastâ€™s cocoa regions could pave the way for an early and strong start to the October-to-March main crop if the weather remains favourable next month, farmers said on Monday.
item.dc:creator: Reuters

item.title: Eastern Australia faces flood risk this spring, weather bureau warns
item.description: Australia faces a 70% chance of La Nina returning this spring, with a high likelihood of wet conditions over the next three months, just after massive floods hit the east coast earlier this year, the country's weather bureau said on Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: Reuters

item.title: U.S. states urge postal service to halt gas vehicle purchases
item.description: A group of 17 state attorneys general urged the U.S. Postal Service (USPS) to halt planned purchases of gasoline-powered delivery vehicles pending a new environmental review, in a statement on Monday that encouraged the purchase of electric vehicles (EVs).
item.dc:creator: Reuters

item.title: Factbox: Why low water levels on the Rhine river hurt Germany's economy
item.description: Water levels on the Rhine river are very low because of unusually hot and dry weather, preventing many vessels from navigating the critical European shipping route fully loaded.
item.dc:creator: Reuters
